title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: First insect-bearing amber found in South America gives clues to forest life 112 million years ago
items.description: Flies, beetles, wasps, and other creatures from the Cretaceous reveal ecosystems details of the Gondwanan supercontinent

items.title: Smart dogs have a humanlike knack for naming new objects
items.description: In games with toys, “gifted” dogs can extend names to new objects with the same purpose as known ones

items.title: USDA funding delays under Trump compromise agricultural research
items.description: Sharp drop in grant awards leaves researchers frustrated

items.title: Delays, uncertainty plague NSF fellowship for graduate students
items.description: After an unusual award process this year, applicants for next year are waiting for overdue guidelines

items.title: NIH promises to create conflict-of-interest database for scientists, but offers few details
items.description: Proposed system would mirror Open Payments program for tracking industry payments to doctors

items.title: Amid war, a Ukrainian genomics research program blooms
items.description: Inaugural project for new center searches for genes involved in diabetes

items.title: Have half of wildebeests in the Serengeti disappeared?
items.description: New satellite method does not align with past estimates from aerial surveys, but some biologists are skeptical

items.title: Neurodegeneration may emerge in football players earlier than previously thought
items.description: Even in athletes without chronic traumatic encephalopathy, brain tissue showed neuron loss and other changes, though their significance isn’t clear

items.title: Scientists make most authentic kidney replicas so far
items.description: Lab-grown organoids reproduce some of a kidney’s internal structure and function

items.title: Notorious ex–weapons factory will lock up nuclear waste in glass—if the White House lets it
items.description: Hanford vitrification plant set to open but some fear Trump officials are pushing for a cheaper alternative
